America is at a crossroads. Humanity is at a crossroads. We can become what we are meant to become ‚Äî one people, one flourishing human family, united by love and respect ‚Äî or we can remain divided by those who profit and build power from our division.  Thanks again to Bishop O.C. Allen III of The Vision Church for having me this morning!

I‚Äôll never know how it feels to be black in America. But I promise you this: As the Senator from Georgia, I‚Äôll work relentlessly to help deliver the justice, equality, and opportunity so long denied to those who do. Black History doesn‚Äôt begin with slavery.  It includes millennia of African civilization before European invasion. Then millions were forced across the Atlantic in chains. Many died in passage.  The survivors and their descendants were enslaved for centuries. The wealth of the South was built upon their forced labor. And after Emancipation, the assault has continued: economic exploitation, lynchings, segregation, Jim Crow, voter suppression, brutality and disenfranchisement delivered by the legal system.  Yet despite centuries of subjugation and dehumanization, African-Americans have overcome violence and intimidation to secure essential political rights ‚Äî an unfinished struggle that must continue. Despite centuries of oppression and exclusion, African-Americans have made selfless, vital, heroic contributions to American history, society, law, business, and culture ‚Äî contributions without which America would not and could not be America at all. Entering #BlackHistoryMonth, I humbly pay respect: Respect to those who have suffered and died, respect to heroes whose names we‚Äôll never know (and those we know well), whose struggle for liberation and commitment to justice should inspire us to build a world where all are free. And I humbly offer recognition and commitment, built on that respect: Recognition that the struggle continues, and commitment to that struggle. #BlackHistoryMonth

Just left a wonderful service at Ebenezer Baptist Church. Amidst bitter confusion about who we are & where we‚Äôre going, Dr. King‚Äôs wisdom should guide us. I don‚Äôt just mean obligatory holiday respects. I mean full engagement with Dr. King‚Äôs leadership & ideas, which are alive. Dr. King‚Äôs vision of the Beloved Community should inspire us to elevate humanity‚Äôs condition. The Beloved Community is at peace because understanding our universal humanity reveals the folly of violence & prejudice.  In the Beloved Community, standards of decency forbid poverty, hunger, and homelessness. But the Beloved Community is not a utopia or fairy tale. Nor is it a place without tension or dispute.  It is instead a realistic ambition. It is our destination. Dr. King said building the Beloved Community ‚Äúwill require a qualitative change in our souls.‚Äù Getting from here to there requires big changes & hard work, including spiritual work. The massive efforts of Dr. King & his allies have already paid off in great progress. At this moment we are falling short.  But I believe Georgians and all people can unite to build a future defined by universal compassion, freedom, health, and opportunity. Dr. King continues to lead us with clear moral vision. Let‚Äôs keep going. #MLKDay
